sen.j: 渡辺氏（わたなべし/わたべし）は、日本の姓氏、氏族、苗字、大姓。
sen.e: Watanabe-shi (the Watanabe clan) is the Japanese surname, the clan name, the family name, or the last name.
Watanabe-shi (the Watanabe clan) or Watabe-shi (the Watabe clan) is the Japanese surname, the clan name, the family name, or the last name.
Watanabe-shi (the Watanabe clan) or Watabe-shi (the Watabe clan) is the Japanese surname, the clan name, the family name, or the last name.

sen.j: 摂津国渡辺よりおこった源氏嵯峨源氏が渡辺氏を称する。
sen.e: Saga-Genji of the Minamoto clan which originated in Watanabe in Settsu Province called themselves the Watanabe clan.
Saga-Genji (the Minamoto clan originated from the Emperor Saga) who emerged in Watanabe in Settsu Province called themselves the Watanabe clan.
sen.cmt: 「嵯峨源氏」の説明を加えました。
sen.e: Saga-Genji (the Minamoto clan originated from the Emperor Saga) who emerged in Watanabe in Settsu Province called themselves the Watanabe clan.

sen.j: 同音異姓に渡邊、渡邉、渡部（わたのべ/わたぶ）、亘鍋、綿鍋、綿奈部、綿辺、渡那部、渡邁、渡鍋（わたしなべ）、綿部がある。
sen.e: As the different surname of the same sound, there are: 渡邊, 渡邉, 渡部 (Watanobe or Watabe), 亘鍋, 綿鍋, 綿奈部, 綿辺, 渡那部, 渡邁, 渡鍋(Watashinabe) and 綿部.
sen.cmt: すべて同音名なので、あえて漢字表記をそのまま残しました。
sen.e: As the different surnames with the same sound, there are 渡邊, 渡邉, 渡部 (Watanobe or Watabu), 亘鍋, 綿鍋, 綿奈部, 綿辺, 渡那部, 渡邁, 渡鍋(Watashinabe) and 綿部.
sen.cmt: surname を複数としました。
sen.e: As the different surnames with the same sound, there are 渡邊, 渡邉, 渡部 (Watanobe or Watabu), 亘鍋, 綿鍋, 綿奈部, 綿辺, 渡那部, 渡邁, 渡鍋(Watashinabe) and 綿部.

sen.j: 異音同姓（わたのべ）に渡野辺、渡延、渡野邊がある。
sen.e: Watanobe, which is the same surname of the different sound, is written 渡野辺, 渡延 or 渡野邊.
sen.cmt: すべて同音名なので、あえて漢字表記をそのまま残しました。
sen.e: As the same surnames with the different sound (pronounced as Watanobe), there are 渡野辺, 渡延 or 渡野邊.
As the same surnames with the different sound (pronounced as Watanobe), there are 渡野辺, 渡延 or 渡野邊.

sen.j: 異音同姓（わたり）に渡利、渡里、亘理、渡、亘、渉、弥、和多利、済、日理、日理、和田利がある。
sen.e: Watari, which is the same surname of the different sound, is written 渡利, 渡里, 亘理, 渡, 亘, 渉, 弥, 和多利, 済, 日理, 日理 or 和田利.
sen.cmt: すべて同音名なので、あえて漢字表記をそのまま残しました。
sen.e: As the same surnames with the different sound (pronounced as Watari), there are 渡利、渡里、亘理、渡、亘、渉、弥、和多利、済、日理、日理、和田利.
As the same surnames with the different sound (pronounced as Watari), there are 渡利、渡里、亘理、渡、亘、渉、弥、和多利、済、日理、日理、和田利.

sen.j: 異音同姓（わたりだ）渡田がある。
sen.e: Watarida, which is the same surname of the different sound, is written 渡田.
sen.cmt: 同音名なので、あえて漢字表記をそのまま残しました。
sen.e: As the same surname with the different sound (pronounced as Watarida), there is 渡田.
As the same surname with the different sound (pronounced as Watarida), there is 渡田.

tit.e: The lineage of MINAMOTO no Toru of Saga-Genji
The lineage of MINAMOTO no Toru of Saga-Genji
The lineage of MINAMOTO no Toru of Saga-Genji

sen.j: 嵯峨源氏の渡辺氏は、嵯峨天皇の皇子である左大臣源融（みなもと・の・とおる）を遠祖とする。
sen.e: The patriarch of the Watanabe clan of Saga-Genji was MINAMOTO no Toru who was the Minister of the Left and the son and the Imperial Prince of Emperor Saga.
The patriarch of the Watanabe clan of Saga-Genji was MINAMOTO no Toru who was the Minister of the Left and the Emperor Saga's prince.
The patriarch of the Watanabe clan of Saga-Genji was MINAMOTO no Toru who was the Minister of the Left and the Emperor Saga's prince.

sen.j: 融の孫の源仕（みなもと・の・つこう）のとき武蔵守となって武蔵国足立郡箕田（埼玉県鴻巣市）に下向。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Tsuko, the grandson of Toru, was given the status of the Governor of Musashi Province and left the capital Kyoto to Mita, Adachi County in Musashi Province (present-day Konosu City, Saitama Prefecture).

MINAMOTO no Tsuko, a grandson of Toru, was appointed as Governor of Musashi Province and left the capital Kyoto for Mita, Adachi County in Musashi Province (present-day Konosu City, Saitama Prefecture).

MINAMOTO no Tsuko, a grandson of Toru, was appointed as Governor of Musashi Province and left the capital Kyoto for Mita, Adachi County in Musashi Province (present-day Konosu City, Saitama Prefecture).

sen.j: 源仕は同地に土着し、地名の箕田（みた）を名字として武士になった。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Tsuko stayed in the place and became a samurai by carrying Mita, the name of the place, as his surname.
MINAMOTO no Tsuko stayed in the place and became a samurai, carrying Mita, the name of the place, as his surname.
sen.cmt: 箕田を名字にすることと、武士になることとの間に因果関係はないので、by は削除しました。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Tsuko stayed in the place and became a samurai, carrying Mita, the name of the place, as his surname.

sen.j: 箕田仕の子が箕田宛（箕田源次宛）。
sen.e: Tsuko MITA's son was Atsuru MITA (Atsuru Genji Mita).
Tsuko MITA's son was Atsuru MITA (Atsuru Genji MITA).
sen.cmt: 括弧内の「箕田」を大文字表記としました。
sen.e: Tsuko MITA's son was Atsuru MITA (Atsuru Genji MITA).

tit.j: 摂津国渡辺氏と摂津源氏
tit.e: The Watanabe clan of Settsu Province and Settsu-Genji

sen.j: 源宛（箕田宛）の子の源綱（みなもと・の・つな）は、摂津国多田(兵庫県川西市)に清和源氏の武士団を形成した源満仲の娘婿である源氏の源敦の養子となり、母方の里である摂津国渡辺（大阪府大阪市中央区 (大阪市)）に居住した。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Atsuru (Atsuru MITA)'s son, MINAMOTO no Tsuna was adopted by MINAMOTO no Atsushi who was the adopted son-in-law of MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka, and lived in Watanabe in Settsu Province (present-day Chuo Ward, Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture).

MINAMOTO no Atsuru (Atsuru MITA)'s son, MINAMOTO no Tsuna was adopted by MINAMOTO no Atsushi, an adopted son-in-law of MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka who formed an armed group consisting of Seiwa-Genji (the Minamoto clan originated from the Emperor Seiwa) in Tada, Settsu Province (present-day Kawanishi City, Hyogo Prefecture), and lived in Watanabe, Settsu Province (present-day Chuo Ward, Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture), his mother's hometown.
sen.cmt: 「摂津国多田（兵庫県川西市）に清和源氏の武士団を形成した」と「母方の里」が抜けていました。
sen.e: MINAMOTO no Atsuru (Atsuru MITA)'s son, MINAMOTO no Tsuna was adopted by MINAMOTO no Atsushi, an adopted son-in-law of MINAMOTO no Mitsunaka who formed an armed group consisting of Seiwa-Genji (the Minamoto clan originated from the Emperor Seiwa) in Tada, Settsu Province (present-day Kawanishi City, Hyogo Prefecture), and lived in Watanabe, Settsu Province (present-day Chuo Ward, Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture), his mother's hometown.

sen.j: 渡辺綱（わたなべ・の・つな。渡辺源次綱。「源次」は綱の父以来、嫡子の通称）と称し、渡辺氏の祖となる。
sen.e: He called himself WATANABE no Tsuna (Tsuna WATANABE-GENJI; 'Genji' is the by-name of the legitimate children since the time of the Tsuna's father) and became the founder of the Watanabe clan.
sen.cmt: 一つ前のセルとまとめました。
sen.e: He called himself WATANABE no Tsuna (渡辺源次綱; '源次' was a common name for the legitimate child since the era of Tsuna's father) and became the founder of the Watanabe clan.
sen.cmt: 「源次」は漢字表記でないと同音の「源氏」と混同すると判断しました。
sen.e: He called himself WATANABE no Tsuna (渡辺源次綱; '源次' was a common name for the legitimate child since the era of Tsuna's father) and became the founder of the Watanabe clan.

sen.j: 渡辺綱は義父の源敦の妻の兄である摂津源氏の源頼光の郎党となった。
sen.e: WATANABE no Tsuna became the retainer of MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu of Settsu-Genji, who was the brother of the wife of MINAMOTO no Atsushi, Tsuna's father-in-law.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: WATANABE no Tsuna became a retainer of MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu of Settsu-Genji (the Minamoto clan based in Settsu), who was the brother of the wife of MINAMOTO no Atsushi, Tsuna's father-in-law.
sen.cmt: 摂津源氏の定訳はよく分からないので、「摂津を拠点とする源氏」としました。
sen.e: WATANABE no Tsuna became a retainer of MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu of Settsu-Genji (the Minamoto clan based in Settsu), who was the brother of the wife of MINAMOTO no Atsushi, Tsuna's father-in-law.

sen.j: 彼は頼光四天王の筆頭とされる。
sen.e: He became the leading member of the four loyal retainers of Yorimitsu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: He is regarded as the leading member of the four loyal retainers of Yorimitsu.
sen.cmt: 「～とされる」の意味を明確にしました。
sen.e: He is regarded as the leading member of the four loyal retainers of Yorimitsu.

sen.j: 源頼光の後裔で摂津国渡辺津に拠る源頼政の郎党として、渡辺氏は、保元の乱において、渡辺省、源授、源連、源興、渡辺競らが参陣している。
sen.e: Of the Watanabe clan, Habuku WATANABE, Sazuku WATANABE, MINAMOTO no Tsuranu, MINAMOTO no Okoru, and Kio WATANABE joined the Hogen Disturbance as the retainers of MINAMOTO no Yorimasa who was the descendant of MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu and who based his headquarter in Watanabe no Tsu in Settsu Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: As a retainer of MINAMOTO no Yorimasa who, as a descendent of MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, was based in Watanabe no Tsu in Settsu Province, the Watanabe clan had Habuku WATANABE, MINAMOTO no Sazuku, MINAMOTO no Tsuranu, MINAMOTO no Okoru, and Kio WATANABE participate in the Hogen Disturbance.

As a retainer of MINAMOTO no Yorimasa who, as a descendent of MINAMOTO no Yorimitsu, was based in Watanabe no Tsu in Settsu Province, the Watanabe clan had Habuku WATANABE, MINAMOTO no Sazuku, MINAMOTO no Tsuranu, MINAMOTO no Okoru, and Kio WATANABE participate in the Hogen Disturbance.

sen.j: 彼らは、源頼政の反平家蜂起の宇治合戦において平家の大軍と戦い討死している。
sen.e: They fought against the large force of the Taira family at the Battle of Uji during the anti-Heike uprising staged by MINAMOTO no Yorimasa, and died in the battle.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: They fought against the large force of the Taira family at the Battle of Uji during the anti-Heike uprising staged by MINAMOTO no Yorimasa, and died in the battle.
They fought against the large force of the Taira family at the Battle of Uji during the anti-Heike uprising staged by MINAMOTO no Yorimasa, and died in the battle.

tit.j: 大江御厨惣官と滝口武者
tit.e: Oe Mikuriya Sokan (the military officer in charge of imperial manors in Oe) and Takiguchi no Musha (samurai guards of the Imperial Residence)
Oe Mikuriya Sokan (the military officer in charge of imperial manors in Oe) and Takiguchi no Musha (samurai guards of the Imperial Residence)
Oe Mikuriya Sokan (the military officer in charge of imperial manors in Oe) and Takiguchi no Musha (samurai guards of the Imperial Residence)

sen.j: 渡辺綱の後裔は、摂津国の渡辺津(大阪市中央区)という旧淀川河口辺の港湾地域を本拠地とする「渡辺党」と呼ばれる武士団を形成し、瀬戸内海の水運に関与した。
sen.e: The descendants of WATANABE no Tsuna formed warrior bands called the 'Watanabe Party' and based themselves around the seaports at the mouth of the former Yodo-gawa River in the place called Watanabe no Tsu in Settsu Province, and were involved in the water transportation business of the Seto Inland Sea.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: The descendants of WATANABE no Tsuna formed the 'Watanabe Party,' an armed group based in Watanabe no Tsu in Settsu Province, the seaport area at the mouth of the Kyu-Yodo-gawa River and were involved in the water transportation business in the Seto Inland Sea.

The descendants of WATANABE no Tsuna formed the 'Watanabe Party,' an armed group based in Watanabe no Tsu in Settsu Province, the seaport area at the mouth of the Kyu-Yodo-gawa River and were involved in the water transportation business in the Seto Inland Sea.

sen.j: 彼らは、瀬戸内海の水軍の棟梁的存在になると共に皇室領の大江御厨を統轄した。
sen.e: As they became the leaders of the Navies in the Seto Inland Sea, they also controlled Oe Mikuriya (the imperial manors in Oe), which was the estates of the Imperial family.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: They became the leaders of the Setouchi (Seto Inland Sea) Navy and also took charge of Oe Mikuriya (the imperial manors in Oe).
sen.cmt: ・「瀬戸内海の水軍」は「瀬戸内水軍」としました。・「大江御厨」の括弧内の説明と which 以下の説明は同じなので、which 以下は削除しました。
sen.e: They became the leaders of the Setouchi (Seto Inland Sea) Navy and also took charge of Oe Mikuriya (the imperial manors in Oe).

sen.j: 京都では内裏で天皇の警護(近衛部隊の前身のようなもの)に就く滝口武者を世襲し、他にも衛門府、兵衛府など中央の官職を有していた。
sen.e: In Kyoto, the members of the Watanabe clan served by succession as Takiguchi no musha (samurai guards of the Imperial Residence) who guarded the Emperor in the Imperial Palace (the forerunner of the Konoe troops), and further, they held central governmental posts in Emonfu (Headquarters of the Outer Palace Guards) and Hyoefu (Headquarters of the Middle Palace Guards).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: In Kyoto, in addition to serving by succession as Takiguchi no musha (samurai guards of the Imperial Residence and the forerunner of the Konoe troops), the members of the Watanabe clan held some central governmental posts including Emonfu (Headquarters of the Outer Palace Guards) and Hyoefu (Headquarters of the Middle Palace Guards).
sen.cmt: 「滝口武者」の括弧内の説明と who 以下の説明は同じなので、who 以下は削除しました。
sen.e: In Kyoto, in addition to serving by succession as Takiguchi no musha (samurai guards of the Imperial Residence and the forerunner of the Konoe troops), the members of the Watanabe clan held some central governmental posts including Emonfu (Headquarters of the Outer Palace Guards) and Hyoefu (Headquarters of the Middle Palace Guards).

tit.e: Sumiyoshi, Settsu Province and the Watanabe Party
Sumiyoshi, Settsu Province and the Watanabe Party
Sumiyoshi, Settsu Province and the Watanabe Party

sen.j: 彼らは摂津国住吉郡の浜（住之江の浜、大阪湾）で行われる天皇の清めの儀式（八十嶋祭）に従事した。
sen.e: The Watanabe clan engaged themselves in the Emperor's purification ritual (Yasoshima Festival) held in the beach of Sumiyoshi County, Settsu Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: The Watanabe clan members were engaged in the imperial purification ritual (Yasoshima Festival) held in the beach of Sumiyoshi County, Settsu Province.
sen.cmt: 特定の天皇の儀式ではなく、皇室の儀式と思われるので、そのように修正しました。
sen.e: The Watanabe clan members were engaged in the imperial purification ritual (Yasoshima Festival) held in the beach of Sumiyoshi County, Settsu Province.

sen.j: 同時に、海上交通を通じて日本全国に散らばり、各地に渡辺氏の支族を残した。
sen.e: At the same time, they scattered all over Japan through the marinetime traffic, and their descendants stayed in various places as the branch families.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: Furthermore, they were scattered all over Japan through the maritime traffic, producing the clan's branch families in various places.
Furthermore, they were scattered all over Japan through the maritime traffic, producing the clan's branch families in various places.

sen.j: 肥前国の松浦氏とその庶氏、松浦党をはじめ、松浦氏族の山代氏に連なる筑後国の蒲池氏、毛利氏重臣の渡辺勝 (戦国武将)、豊臣氏家臣の渡辺糺などは子孫である。
sen.e: The Matsuura clan as well as the Matsuura Party as its branch clan, the Kamachi clan in Chikugo Province which was connected to the Yamashiro clan of the Matsuura clan, Masaru WATANABE (military commander in the Sengoku period) who was the senior vassal of the Mori clan, and Tadasu WATANEBE are their descendants.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: The Matsuura clan in Hizen Province and its branch clan, the Matsuura Party, the Kamachi clan in Chikugo Province related to the Yamashiro clan who belonged to the Matsuura clan, Masaru WATANABE (military commander in the Sengoku period) who was the senior vassal of the Mori clan, and Tads WATANABE, a vassal of the Toyota clan, are the descendants.
sen.cmt: ・表現の修正・「肥前国」が抜けていました。
sen.e: The Matsuura clan in Hizen Province and its branch clan, the Matsuura Party, the Kamachi clan in Chikugo Province related to the Yamashiro clan who belonged to the Matsuura clan, Masaru WATANABE (military commander in the Sengoku period) who was the senior vassal of the Mori clan, and Tads WATANABE, a vassal of the Toyota clan, are the descendants.

sen.j: また大阪の坐摩神社の宮司家は渡辺契の、お初天神として有名な大阪曾根崎の露天神社の社家は渡辺薫の子孫である。
sen.e: Also, the Guji family of Zama-jinja Shrine in Osaka is the descendants of 渡辺契, and shake (family of Shinto priests serving a shrine on a hereditary basis) of Tsuyunoten-jinja Shrine at Sonezaki, Osaka, commonly known as Ohatsu-tenjin, is the descendants of Kaoru WATANABE.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。渡辺契と渡辺薫の読み方を確認できませんでした。
sen.e: Also, the Fuji family of Zama-ninja Shrine in Osaka is a descendant of 渡辺契, and the shake (family of Shinto priests serving a shrine on a hereditary basis) of Tsuyunoten-jinja Shrine at Sonezaki, Osaka, commonly known as Ohatsu-tenjin, is a descendant of 渡辺薫.
sen.cmt: 渡辺両名の読みは確認できませんでした。「渡辺薫」は一応候補となる読みが与えられていますが、確定的ではないので、日本語表記に戻しました。
sen.e: Also, the Fuji family of Zama-ninja Shrine in Osaka is a descendant of 渡辺契, and the shake (family of Shinto priests serving a shrine on a hereditary basis) of Tsuyunoten-jinja Shrine at Sonezaki, Osaka, commonly known as Ohatsu-tenjin, is a descendant of 渡辺薫.

sen.j: 徳川氏譜代の渡辺守綱にはじまる渡辺氏もまたその子孫を称する。
sen.e: The Watanabe clan, fudai (hereditary daimyo) of the Tokugawa clan was started by Moritsuna WATANEBE and were also the descendants of the Watanabe clan.
The Watanabe clan, a fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) starting with Moritsuna WATANEBE, claimed to be a descendant of the Watanabe clan.
The Watanabe clan, a fudai daimyo (a daimyo in hereditary vassal to the Tokugawa family) starting with Moritsuna WATANEBE, claimed to be a descendant of the Watanabe clan.

tit.j: 徳川譜代の三河国渡辺氏
tit.e: The Watanabe clan of the Mikawa Province as Tokugawa fudai
The Watanabe clan of Mikawa Province as Tokugawa fudai
tit.cmt: 定冠詞を削除しました。
tit.e: The Watanabe clan of Mikawa Province as Tokugawa fudai

sen.j: のちの徳川譜代渡辺氏は、渡辺綱の後裔を称し、綱のひ孫の源正（源次正、小源次正、源公頼）の流れを汲むという。
sen.e: The subsequent Watanabe clan of Tokugawa fudai called themselves as the descendant of WATANABE no Tsuna, and it is said that they are descended from the great grandchildren of Tsuna (源次正, 小源次正, MINAMOTO no Kimiyori).
sen.cmt: 源次正、小源次正、源公頼の読み方を確認できませんでした。
sen.e: The Watanabe clan members in later days, who claimed to be the descendants of WATANABE no Tsuna, are reportedly descended from his great grandchildren (源次正, 小源次正, 源公頼).
sen.cmt: 3名の名前の読みは確認できませんでした。源公頼も「きみより」もしくは「きんより」の可能性もあるので、日本語表記に戻しました。
sen.e: The Watanabe clan members in later days, who claimed to be the descendants of WATANABE no Tsuna, are reportedly descended from his great grandchildren (源次正, 小源次正, 源公頼).

sen.j: 系譜によれば足利将軍家に直臣として仕え、のちに三河国に移住したとされる。
sen.e: According to the genealogical record, they served as the direct vassals of the Shogun Ashikaga family, and later moved to the Mikawa Province.
According to a genealogical record, they served as the direct vassals of the Ashikaga Shogun family, and later moved to Mikawa Province.
According to a genealogical record, they served as the direct vassals of the Ashikaga Shogun family, and later moved to Mikawa Province.

sen.j: 三河の渡辺党は松平氏に代々仕えて功があったが、浄土真宗の門徒であったために三河一向一揆で松平家康（徳川家康）に反旗を翻し、一族の者が多く戦死した。
sen.e: Although the Watanabe Party in Mikawa received recognition for serving the Matsudaira clan for generations, as they were the followers of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism), they rebelled against Ieyasu MATSUDAIRA (Ieyasu TOKUGAWA) at Mikawa Ikko Ikki; Mikawa Ikko Ikki (an uprising of Ikko sect followers in Mikawa Province) and many members of the family died in the battle.

Although the Watanabe Party members in Mikawa worked well for the Matsudaira clan for generations, they, as the followers of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism), rebelled against Ieyasu MATSUDAIRA (Ieyasu TOKUGAWA) when the Mikawa Ikko Ikki (an uprising of Ikko sect followers in Mikawa Province) broke out, and many members of the party died in the battle.

Although the Watanabe Party members in Mikawa worked well for the Matsudaira clan for generations, they, as the followers of Jodo Shinshu (the True Pure Land Sect of Buddhism), rebelled against Ieyasu MATSUDAIRA (Ieyasu TOKUGAWA) when the Mikawa Ikko Ikki (an uprising of Ikko sect followers in Mikawa Province) broke out, and many members of the party died in the battle.

sen.j: 三河一向一揆に生き残った一族の渡辺守綱は、一揆鎮圧後も許されて家康に仕え、1590年、関東入国に際して武蔵国比企郡に3千石を与えられた。
sen.e: Moritsuna WATANABE, who survived Mikawa Ikko Ikki, received a pardon from Ieyasu after the suppression of the uprising and served for him, and in 1590, he was given the territory worth 3,000 koku in Hiki County, Musashi Province when he entered the Kanto region.

Moritsuna WATANABE, a survivor of the Mikawa Ikko Ikki, who received a pardon from a Ieyasu after the suppression of the uprising and served him, was given the territory of 3,000 koku crop yields in Hiki County, Musashi Province when he entered the Kanto region in 1590.

Moritsuna WATANABE, a survivor of the Mikawa Ikko Ikki, who received a pardon from a Ieyasu after the suppression of the uprising and served him, was given the territory of 3,000 koku crop yields in Hiki County, Musashi Province when he entered the Kanto region in 1590.

sen.j: 1613年、守綱は尾張徳川家に配属されて三河国加茂郡 (三河国)寺部（愛知県豊田市）に1万4千石を領した。
sen.e: In 1613, Moritsuna was placed in Owari-Tokugawa family, and received the territory worth 14,000 koku in Terabe, Kamo County, Mikawa Province (present-day Toyota City, Aichi Prefecture).
In 1613, Moritsuna was assigned to the Owari-Tokugawa family and received the territory of 14,000 koku crop yields in Terabe, Kamo County, Mikawa Province (present-day Toyota City, Aichi Prefecture).
In 1613, Moritsuna was assigned to the Owari-Tokugawa family and received the territory of 14,000 koku crop yields in Terabe, Kamo County, Mikawa Province (present-day Toyota City, Aichi Prefecture).

sen.j: 守綱の嫡男重綱は尾張藩家老となり、子孫は1万石を領して尾張藩の重臣として続いた。
sen.e: Shigetsuna, the legitimate son of Moritsuna, became the chief retainer of the Owari Domain, and his descendants inherited the territory worth 10,000 koku as the senior vassals of the Owari Domain.

Shigetsuna, the legitimate son of Moritsuna, became the chief retainer of the Owari Domain, and his descendants inherited the territory of 10,000 koku crop yields as the senior vassals of the Owari Domain.

Shigetsuna, the legitimate son of Moritsuna, became the chief retainer of the Owari Domain, and his descendants inherited the territory of 10,000 koku crop yields as the senior vassals of the Owari Domain.

sen.j: 明治維新後、華族に列し男爵を授けられる。
sen.e: After the Meiji Restoration, they were raised to the peerage and received the title of Baron.
After the Meiji Restoration, the descendants of the Watanabe clan were raised to the peerage and baronized.
After the Meiji Restoration, the descendants of the Watanabe clan were raised to the peerage and baronized.

sen.j: 重綱は父が幕府から直接拝領していた武蔵領3000石を三男の忠綱に与えた。
sen.e: Shigetsuna passed down the territory in Musashi worth 3,000 koku, which was his father's territory given directly from bakufu, to his third son Tadatsuna.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: Shigetsuna passed down the territory in Musashi of 3,000 koku crop yields, which was given to his father directly from bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), to his third son Tadatsuna.

Shigetsuna passed down the territory in Musashi of 3,000 koku crop yields, which was given to his father directly from bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), to his third son Tadatsuna.

sen.j: 忠綱の早逝後はその弟吉綱に与え、直参旗本とした。
sen.e: After the early death of Tadatsuna, the territory was given to his younger brother Yoshitsuna who became the jikisan (immediate) hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処しました。
sen.e: After the early death of Tadatsuna, the territory was given to his younger brother Yoshitsuna who became the jikisan (immediate) hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu).
After the early death of Tadatsuna, the territory was given to his younger brother Yoshitsuna who became the jikisan (immediate) hatamoto (direct retainers of the bakufu).

sen.j: 吉綱は大坂定番に任ぜられ、和泉国・河内国に1万石を加増されて大名に列す。
sen.e: Yoshitsuna was given the post as the Guard of Osaka-jo Castle, and his status was raised to daimyo when he also received the territories worth 10,000 koku in Izumi Province and Kawachi Province.
Appointed as a Guard of Osaka-jo Castle, Yoshistsuna received the territories in Izumi and Kawachi Provinces totaling 10,000 koku crop yields and was raised to daimyo (feudal lord).
Appointed as a Guard of Osaka-jo Castle, Yoshistsuna received the territories in Izumi and Kawachi Provinces totaling 10,000 koku crop yields and was raised to daimyo (feudal lord).

sen.j: その子孫はのちに和泉大庭寺を経て伯太（大阪府和泉市）に居所を移し、伯太藩1万3千石の藩主となった。
sen.e: His descendants moved to Izumi Obadera and later to Hakata (Izumi City, Osaka Prefecture), and became the lord of the Hakata Domain worth 13,000 koku.
After having stayed in Izumi Obadera, his descendants moved to Hakata (Izumi City, Osaka Prefecture) and served as the lord of the Hakata Domain of 13,000 koku crop yields.
After having stayed in Izumi Obadera, his descendants moved to Hakata (Izumi City, Osaka Prefecture) and served as the lord of the Hakata Domain of 13,000 koku crop yields.

sen.j: この家は明治に至り子爵を授けられる。
sen.e: This family was given the status of Viscount during the Meiji period.
This family was appointed viscount during the Meiji period.
This family was appointed viscount during the Meiji period.

sen.j: ミセス・ワタナベ
sen.e: Mrs. Watanabe
Mrs. Watanabe
Mrs. Watanabe

sen.j: FX取引をする日本の主婦たちが世界経済に影響力を持つことがある。
sen.e: Japanese housewives who are engaged in foreign exchange trades can at times have an influence on the world economy.
Japanese housewives who are engaged in foreign exchange trades can have an influence on the world economy.
sen.cmt: at times を削除しました。
sen.e: Japanese housewives who are engaged in foreign exchange trades can have an influence on the world economy.

sen.j: 彼女達を総称して、Mrs.Watanabe ミセス・ワタナベということがある。
sen.e: They are sometimes called Mrs. Watanabe collectively.
They are sometimes called Mrs. Watanabe collectively.
They are sometimes called Mrs. Watanabe collectively.
